question_details.query: What are the long-term effects of using municipal waste compost on soil fertility over a 20-year period?

summary_details.relevant_summary: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding municipal wastes or their composts to the soil [890]. One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff [890]. The other found mixed results of adding composts and wastes [890]. The soil types covered were coarse loamy and sandy loam [890]. Two other controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding organic processing wastes or their composts to soil [891]. One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure and reduced soil loss, but increased nutrient loss [891]. The other trial found improved nutrient retention and increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added [891]. The soil types covered were sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay [891].
summary_statements: Two controlled, replicated trials in Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding municipal wastes or composts from municipal wastes to the soil.
One trial found that adding municipal compost to semi-arid soils greatly reduced soil loss and water runoff.
Another trial found mixed results from adding composts and wastes to soil.
The soil types covered in the trials on municipal wastes were coarse loamy and sandy loam.
Two other controlled, replicated trials from Spain and the United Kingdom measured the effect of adding organic processing wastes or composts from organic processing wastes to soil.
One trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure improved soil structure.
A trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure reduced soil loss.
A trial found that applying high rates of cotton gin compost and poultry manure increased nutrient loss.
Another trial found improved nutrient retention when molasses were added to soil.
Another trial found increased barley Hordeum vulgare yield when molasses were added to soil.
The soil types covered in trials on organic processing wastes were sandy-clay, sandy loam, and silty-clay.
